steps.title: Getting Started
steps.body:
This guide will walk you through writing your first few lines of code with voice. We’ll go through a few different examples that cover adding, navigating, and editing code.

To start, click Next below.

steps.title: Setup
steps.body:
Serenade will send voice commands to whichever application you have in the foreground. You can see which application Serenade is controlling via the icon at the bottom-right.

To get started, open VS Code, Atom, or JetBrains, then click next.

steps.title: Setup
steps.body: Before we start the tutorial, let's make sure we're using an empty file. In your editor (without using voice), create a new file and save it as serenade.rb.

steps.title: Alternatives
steps.body:
As you speak, you’ll see a numbered list of possible commands appear below. The first command runs automatically when you’ve finished speaking. To select a different command, just say its number, like “two” or “three”, and Serenade will run that command instead.

Let's get started! First, toggle the listening switch above to enable Serenade. Then, say:

steps.title: Understanding commands
steps.body:
Most Serenade commands consist of an action followed by a selector.

An action describes what you're trying to do, like “go to”, “add”, or “insert”. A selector describes the object you're trying to change, like a “line”, “word”, “function”, or “class”.

We'll see examples throughout this tutorial! To continue, say:

steps.title: Inserting code
steps.body: We'll start with one of the most common actions, “insert”. The “insert” action will insert text directly at your cursor. Try it out by saying:
steps.transcript: insert message equals string hello world

steps.title: Undo
steps.body: You should now see some code in your editor! To undo any command, you can simply say “undo”. Try it out:
steps.source: message = 'Hello world'

steps.title: Writing code
steps.body:
In this first example, we’re going to write a factorial function from scratch.

To continue, say:

steps.title: Writing a factorial function
steps.body:
Take a look at your editor—that's the code we'll be writing with voice.

When you're ready to start, say:
steps.source:
def factorial(number)
  if number == 0
    return 1
  end
  else
    return number * factorial(number - 1)
  end
end
value = factorial(5)
steps.resetSource:
def factorial(number)
  if number == 0
    return 1
  end
  else
    return number * factorial(number - 1)
  end
end
value = factorial(5)

steps.title: Adding a function
steps.body:
While “insert” inserts text at your cursor, the “add” action is used to create new statements and constructs like functions or classes, without needing to dictate any boilerplate.

Let's give it a try! Create a new function called factorial by saying:

steps.title: Adding a parameter
steps.body: That function will need a parameter, so add one with:
steps.source:
def factorial
end

steps.title: Adding a condition
steps.body: Next, let's add a condition to check if the number parameter we just added equals zero. Say:
steps.source:
def factorial(number)
end

steps.title: Adding a statement
steps.body: Now, add a return statement by saying:
steps.source:
def factorial(number)
  if number == 0
  end
end

steps.title: Adding a branch
steps.body: Great! Now our if branch is done. Let's create an else branch by saying:
steps.source:
def factorial(number)
  if number == 0
    return 1
  end
end

steps.title: Finishing the function
steps.body:
So far, we've been using short commands, but you can also dictate longer commands with Serenade.

Let's try finishing up the factorial function with a single voice command. Say:
steps.source:
def factorial(number)
  if number == 0
    return 1
  else
  end
end
steps.transcript: add return number times factorial of number minus one

steps.title: Navigating code
steps.body:
Now that we have a working factorial function, let's call it! First, we need to move the cursor to the next line.

You can move your cursor with the “go to” action. Try it out by saying:
steps.source:
def factorial(number)
  if number == 0
    return 1
  else
    return number * factorial(number - 1)
  end
end

steps.title: Adding a call
steps.body:
Now, we can add a line of code that calls our factorial function.

Say:
steps.source:
def factorial(number)
  if number == 0
    return 1
  else
    return number * factorial(number - 1)
  end
end
steps.transcript: add value equals factorial of five

steps.title: Writing code
steps.body:
Congrats, you just wrote your first code with voice!

Now that we've covered some commands for adding new code, let's try editing some existing code.

To continue, say:
steps.source:
def factorial(number)
  if number == 0
    return 1
  else
    return number * factorial(number - 1)
  end
end
value = factorial(5)

steps.body:
When adding or changing text, you can also specify how to format the text with “underscores”, “camel case”, “pascal case”, and so on.

steps.body:
Nice job! Now you know some commands for adding, navigating, and editing code.

For this last example, you'll be writing some code on your own. Don't fret—if you get stuck, just click “show hint”.

When you're ready to start, say:

steps.title: Adding a function
steps.body:
We're going to write a function that takes a name as a parameter, then prints out a greeting.

First, create a function called say_hello.

steps.title: Adding a parameter
steps.body: Nice job! Next, add a parameter to your function called name.
steps.source:
def say_hello
end

steps.title: Adding a statement
steps.body:
Let's start writing the body of our function. First, add the line:

message = 'hello'
steps.source:
def say_hello(name)
end

steps.title: Inserting text
steps.body:
Next, insert the following on the current line:

+ name

steps.title: Adding a call
steps.body:
Great! Now we can print out the message variable. Add the line:

puts message

steps.title: Navigating code
steps.body: Let's make one last edit to our function. First, move your cursor to line 1.
steps.source:
def say_hello(name)
  message = "Hello" + name
  puts message
end

steps.title: Changing text
steps.body: Finally, let's change the name of the function from say_hello to print_greeting
steps.source:
def say_hello(name)
  message = "Hello" + name
  puts message
end
steps.transcript: change say hello to print greeting

steps.title: Congrats!
steps.body: Awesome! We've covered the basics of adding, navigating, and editing code. Here are a few more tips for getting started with Serenade.
steps.source:
def print_greeting(name)
  message = "Hello" + name
  puts message
end
